comment: The homework assignments and tests are pretty easy and straightforward to get As on for the most part. But, he fails to give straightforward and clear instructions on assignments. If you email him for clarification about assignment requirements, he will answer with more questions.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Tough grader

comment: Prof. Stabler is easily the worst professor I've ever had the displeasure of having. He was utterly negligent in this class. Rubrics were never given, guidance was rare. It took him over a MONTH to grade each test. His feedback is condescending and utterly unhelpful. No one understands his grading system. I'd write much more if I could... AVOID.

Gave a semester long group project in which his instructions for the it were extraordinarily vague, and anyone who emailed him with questions got a useless, unhelpful response back. He grades you not in letter grades, but with plusses, which made it more difficult to figure out your grade. Long tests with vague answers needed. I do not recommend.

His class overall was simple and easy, most if not all the homework and quizzes are a copy and paste from quizlets, and sites online. However, the project givin to us was made super vague on what to do and feedback when you ask him a question is also vague or useless. His grade scaling is also unclear as it is made by a symbol system, not numbers

A pretty funny character but a horrible professor. He is a total jerk to you in emails for just asking simple questions. His grading system requires you to perform advance calculus, burn sage, call on your God and look into a crystal ball just to figure out what your grade is. Seriously his grading system is impossible to understand.

Homework wasn't hard, but it was pretty much always there. Do a test set, then do another test set, then do another test set. JUnit ALL THE TIME. Which, since this is a testing class, made sense I guess? If Java was the only language in the world. I'd like to have learned more about the rest of the way testing works.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Group projects

comment: Hard class, but he said it had been redesigned and he didn't like it being this hard, either. He made it interesting but I wish we didn't have to write so much. I'd avoid the class, but he's okay, if you like someone that talks a lot. I'd never seen his grading system before but it wasn't difficult to understand. In the end, hard work but easy A.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--SO MANY PAPERS

comment: Prof Stabler is using a grading system called "specification grading" where your grade is based on passing (equals) and you get pluses if you do work beyond just passing. It makes sense but there are no numbers which can be difficult for people that really need to know if they have an 89 or 90. If you have +++, you have an A, easy. Good lectures.

David Stabler is a peculiar professor. Whenever you try to contact him for information, you are met with an incredibly demeaning and sarcastic response that is in no way professional. Rather than being graded as any other professor would grade(A-F), Prof. Stabler uses a plus system, in which I still do not know how to interpret.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--SO MANY PAPERS

comment: Literally a horrible professor. Extremely disrespectful when you ask him to clear up any confusion you have. Very pretentious with feedback and grading. Asks way too much for what the class is and adds secret requirements that aren't on the rubric. Loves to give out bad grades and request too many citations, more than any English professor would.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: He'd be fine if he communicated more clearly to his online students. He also counted off points for saying our opinions were "wrong", which is laughable to hear from an ethics professor. You should promote discussion in an ethics class. Grading based on whether we agree with your opinion defeats the entire purpose of the class.

Stabler is very knowledgeable about his subject and appreciates people who take interest. Most of the work for this class can be done outside of class and you will learn a lot! This is probably the class I learned the most in this semester. His exams are very straight forward. Recommend taking him over anyone else!

Grades according to this odd but simple criteria. Hes a very knowledgeable man. All you need is posted on D2L. Hes very clear what you need to know for the tests. Recommend earning the easy As on the articles. Never showed to class except exam days. Recommend.

Good Ethics teacher, to be graded all you have to "Tecnically" do is do the weekly discussion posts, and a single paper and some review of other persons papers, however lectures are usually entertaining. Textbook is suggested but I never used it and got a A/B

Lectures are long and hardly reinforced by the pointless papers he assigns. I even wish he would assign homework exercises that were relevant to the material so I could learn something. He rambles a lot that doesn't really add a whole lot of meaning to what he's saying, either, so when it's time for a test, you have to learn a lot on your own.

One of the worst professors I've ever had. Wouldn't recommend even if he's the only prof teaching the class. Very unclear grading criteria, will grade based on whether or not he agrees with you (not content or quality). Will require a ridiculous amount of reading/writing and will make you do WAY more work than any other prof. VERY creepy! AVOID!!!!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Stabler is a stickler. Should be an easy A but it isnt. If you dont do an assignment the way he would do it, youll get a B. Lots of busy work. A big negative is he is a terrible writer so there is no clarifiticafion in anything. Avoid.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: You do use the textbooks for disscusions. There is a lot of reading and writing for disscusions and replies, mid-term paper, research papper, and peer review(s). The professor is a though grader but fair. The organization of the course work was right on point. Instructions were very clear and easy to understand.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--Would take again

comment: Really knows the material, but you have to do a LOT of work to get going on this class.  He teaches an entire programming language (C++) in two weeks and expects  you to use it the rest of the semester - this works, but only because you reinforce it the rest of the class.  He's good, and tough, but the class needs to be longer or broken up.

For a CS instructor he had no clue how to use the D2L system. It took him too long to respond to questions through email, did not give feedback in a timely manner, and did not provide lectures even after most of the students begged him to provide some. If he is the only instructor for CS 5423, I am transferring to a new school next semester!

Read a chapter or sections of a chapter every week. Required postings, which is normal for an online class. He is very prompt on answering his students and makes any confusion very clear. He also mediates the discussions very well.
Hard, but insightful

Really knows his stuff, but a pain about code design. That was the class focus, but he didn't budge much on style over function. Wraps disparate concepts up into each lecture, though, which connects the class to the rest of the program.  That was helpful, in later classes.
